awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Theory of Optomechanical Nanorotation Sensing - Approaching the Quantum Regime
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern society is critically reliant on rotation sensing technologies, as evidenced by gyroscopes which regulate cellular phones, ships and airplanes, and global positioning system satellites. This CAREER project aims to meet the continuing demand for better optical sensing of mechanical rotation currently posed by a variety of fields such as nanoscience, precision measurement, remote sensing, and quantum computing. The activity addresses these demands by combining powerful sensing paradigms from the field of linear motion detection with the ability of light to carry orbital angular momentum. It will provide theoretical solutions which can be implemented using available technologies. The ultimate objectives of this research are to develop techniques for measuring mechanical rotation at the quantum level, and thus to identify and to circumvent the limits placed by quantum mechanics on the sensor capabilities. These activities are concomitant with strong technological impact on society, since they aim to establish the route for taking rotation sensor technology to its limits.

This research project will investigate the sensing of nanomechanical rotation in the quantum regime. The proposed sensors will find hitherto undetected torques created by the electromagnetic vacuum, characterize rotational quantum states of macroscopic mechanical systems, allow the nondestructive study of quantized superflow in quantum gases, and measure the rotation of single atoms. The main ideas will combine the established techniques of vibrational optomechanics with the capabilities of optical beams carrying orbital angular momentum. The specific methods will draw on the toolbox of quantum optics and atomic physics techniques. The research program will be integrated with an education plan which includes collaborative visits for students to the Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, introduction of the orbital angular momentum of light into the undergraduate Quantum Optics laboratory at the Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT), and exhibition of rotational toys to the public vis-à-vis the yearly Imagine RIT event as well as the Science Saturdays at the Rochester Museum and Science Center.

por.por_cntn:
Project Report: NSF CAREER Award

 

The outcomes of this project related to intellectual merit addressed broadly the current pressing demand for the ultrasensitive optical detection of nanorotation by developing novel theoretical solutions which can be implemented by available technologies.

The outcomes included characterization of torsional oscillations of a nanoparticle placed inside an optical cavity and of rotation of a nanoparticle inside an optical fiber. As part of an international collaboration, a new technique for spatially sorting light beams with different angular momenta was proposed and demonstrated. With collaborators from the laser micromachining industry, a theoretical explanation of the conservation of laser beam extremal ellipticity was presented by relating it to orbital angular momentum. Experimental data on the optical rotation of crystals containing a small number of trapped ions was accurately modeled, including rotational actuation and quenching. By applying the techniques of gravitational wave detection to superfluid rotation, a theoretical proposal was published on the minimally destructive, in situ and real-time measurement of the angular momentum of a Bose-Einstein condensate of atoms. Many of the research results were combined and presented in a simplified form as a tutorial on optomechanics based on the exchange of angular momentum between light and mechanical motion.

The outcomes of this project related to broader impact addressed the training of students for the scientific and technological workplace and outreach to the public. One undergraduate student was taken to visit the PI?s collaborator at the Indian Institute of Technology in Kanpur, India for about two weeks. An undergraduate student who was an underrepresented minority was a co-author on a publication. Overall, the project involved six undergraduates, four postdoctoral associates and ten external collaborators.

An experiment was added to the quantum optics teaching laboratory at the author?s home institution to relay the fundamental importance of angular momentum carried by light. As part of public outreach, mechanical-rotational toys such as tippe tops, rattlebacks and gyroscopes were displayed to middle-school students as well as the general public at the annual exhibition Imagine RIT on campus. These demonstrations were handled by undergraduate members of the Society of Physics.
